subject: RE: [junit] Why dont we have an option like Assert.assertIsEmpty() in JUnit
msgSnippet: You can always use Assert.assertTrue(coll.isEmpty()); I prefer Assert.assertEquals(0, coll.size()); because if the assertion fails, you get a little more

You can always use
    Assert.assertTrue(coll.isEmpty());
 
I prefer
    Assert.assertEquals(0, coll.size());
because if the assertion fails, you get a little more information about
the state of the bad collection.
 
..David..

anish ephrem
Sent: Tuesday, January 24, 2006 9:42 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Why dont we have an option like Assert.assertIsEmpty()
in JUnit


Hi All,
   
  I am new to JUnit . In one of my test program using JUnit, i want to
check wheather a collection is empty or not. I am not able to find out a
proper method (Assert) that  helps to check wheather the collection is
empty or not.
   
  Generally  we have like Assert.assertequals() , or like
Assert.assertNull() , etc..
  Why dont we have like Assert.assertIsEmpty() ..  Is there any other
method to check it.
   
  Thanks ,
   
  A.Anish Ephrem
